column2: cllmmaybjm, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I had been seeing a therapist for two months after a dramatic incident. Somewhere along the third month she told me to see a psychiatrist, who prescribed me ambien 10mg cr(highest dosage) for my insomnia. The ambien didn't only not help me sleep, but also made sleeping more difficult. I was on ambien for a month and a half, and within that time period I: woke up 5 different times having sex (twice not with my boyfriend), driving my car on the wrong side of the road, in downtown detroit at three in the morning, and making every food in my fridge> i would have to hide my money because if i didn't my money would be missing. My younger brother told me that several times i tried hooking up with him, i was told i good naked excessively when i would go places. While i was on the medication i would feel anxious, i saw more things than i did on LSD, and i felt very uncomfortable all the time, i was however more open to discuss my problems, i don't remember though. While on Ambien i would steal any kind of pill to sell it and make money off it to buy more ambien, I got so addicted that within that month and a half i got a total of three different doctors to prescribe me a month supply. so yes i took about twice the amount prescribed, not including the ambien i was being off the streets. when i wasn't prescribed a fourth script i started taking xanax after my doctor gave me that for my anxiety, not even a month deep i was out of money, doctors, ideas, and people to use. It got so bad i ended up in the mental hospital for 5 days. Im not saying that will be the end all be all for taking ambien, but i am say: if you do take it, be careful! I'm sure it has helped many people, but unfortunately it destroyed my life. try melatonin, its natural and is a chemical already found in your brain. I do not take anything for my on-set insomnia, i just let it ride out and try to get sleep when ever my body will let me. its a pain when i work and i havnt slept in days. i wish you all the best

column2: Is Ambien worth it?, 35-44 Female  (Patient)
column9: I started taking Ambien after 911. Living in lower Manhattan made like really stressful. I slept great an felt good when I woke up. But was told I say and did things I could not remember the next day like order stuff on line, making phone calls, cooking weird food, displaying uninhibited sexual behaviors.  As my life stresses became bigger I turned to Ambien at night to escape the days worries, just to shut my brain down and rest.  I started working night shift and found only Ambien helped me sleep right away in the day because I could not block out the noises.  So here stated my addiction.  After 12 years on Ambien I'm up to 15-20 mg to get to sleep at night or I am up until 6am the next day.  My only fear is that I will burn down the house one night because I tend to get hungry after taking Ambien so I cook weird dishes and fall asleep, leaving the pot on the stove. (scary at times) either my daughter will smell it and wake up or the next morning the pot and it's contents are unrecognisable.  I try to eat before taking Ambien or take it with a snack.  I've really been thinking about trying something else less risky. Because soon my daughter will be off to college and I won't have anyone to get up and turn off the stove:(

column2: 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
Be of good cheer!, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Ambien never could do for me what was expected of it and not being able to stay asleep long enough/night has been a chronic problem especially having to deal with manic-depression. Recently there have been warnings about these newer classes of sleep medications!  I was taking 10mg/night allowing for 7 to 8 hours sleep time but began only sleeping ~ 4 hours/night. I've been taken off Ambien and now take the 5mg or 10mg Melatonin 30 min. before my bedtime.(The 10mg of Melatonin is a time-release formula & have been sleeping ~ 8 hours/night). Last night I've just started Seroquel XR 200mg/night taken about 2 to 3 hours before bedtime and also taking the 5mg Melatonin 30 min. prior to bedtime also as advised by my Dr. As of the first night's changes, I slept 8 hours or more. I'd even drank a cup of coffee about an hour before taking the Seroquel XR which I later thought would ruin my chances of sleeping as well but it didn't. Although if I were going to drink coffee before bedtime, I think 4 to 6 hours prior would be advisable. In the case of sleep aids I would highly recommend that a person consult their pharmacist and/or Dr. before proceeding with these combinations. Walmart carries the Melatonin varieties at very reasonable prices. Have a great day!

column2: Darkspring3, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I have been taking Ambien for about a year one or two nights per week when I had trouble falling asleep. The longer I used the Ambien I found I was having increased problems falling asleep and I began having bouts of extreme fatigue while driving as I used the drug more frequently. Two mornings ago I found my vehicle, which was in the driveway, with all of the windows completely down. I had no explanation for the occurrence. They had been up when I arrived home after dark and it was a cool evening. I never open the windows, and I always lock the vehicle. The ignition key is required to open them as they are power windows. I was relieved that the car had not been driven and that everything of value was still in place. The only conclusion I could come to is that I had gotten up from my bed, in the night, and gone outside and used the key fob to unlock the car and then turn on the ignition and roll down the windows. I woke up in bed with no knowledge of any of this. I have no previous history of behavior of this type. I was not experiencing any of these symptoms before taking the Ambien more frequently. My conclusion is that this drug is not a good fit for me... I will never take it again.

column9: I'm in a high risk pregnancy again and people need to sleep, especially pregnant women. It's excellent, i have tried all sorts of other medications and am allergic to benedryl, so i can't take over the counter sleep aids. ambien keeps me asleep until i wake up to my alarm in the morning and the best part: I FEEL FULLY REFRESHED and not groggy or moody at all. it's like a genie in a bottle. I take it when i need to, it has helped me to get into the swing of falling asleep by myself. I started taking it every night 10mg tablet and then went to an every other night and now I'm down to maybe twice a week. last week i didn't take it at all. column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I started taking 5mg of this medication over a year ago because I have had trouble falling asleep for years. I follow the directions to the letter. Take it on an empty stomach, no alcohol, go directly to bed, devote plenty of time for sleep (at least 7 hours). I also don't leave the tv on because of the flashing lights and sounds. I usually read for about 20 minutes until the medication kicks in and fall asleep easily staying asleep all night. I have had no side effects except for a few hallucinations when my boyfriend keeps me awake past the time when the medication starts working. I know they are hallucinations when I'm having them, they are pleasant and I know I just need to go to sleep. I have stayed on the same dose but I also only take it several times a week. This medication along with a night time routine is really helpful in establishing good sleep patterns. Best advise: start out on the lowest dose possible, increase very slowly if needed and follow the directions.

column2: bdmac, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: Ambien is effective for sleep disorders.  I used it for four years but developed severe anxiety attacks during waking hours.  It is also very expensive.  It resulted in disruption of cognitive ability.  It is EXTREMELY addictive which I found when I tried to stop taking it.  I even wrote the manufacturer asking how to get off their product.  The company had an attorney call me and asked a zillion questions then stated the company would get back to me.  They NEVER DID.  I did finally break the addiction after several attempts over a few months.  I did not sleep for six days on my last attempt but the end result was I broke the addiction.  It was very stressful.  Ambien was initially prescribed and stated as NON ADDICTIVE.  I hope someone begins a class action suit against the manufacturer, I would be happy to join it.

column2: oldsarge, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: My wife has been on this medication for years now and cannot fall asleep without it now. However, she does get a good night's sleep without any side effects. I'm now going to try it. I've had a couple of her pills and they worked well for me. Medication affects us differently as people are chemically made up in many different ways. Lifestyles and other medications do have an effect on side effects. Any medication that goes to the brain has a tendency to do strange things to some, but not all. Are you laid back? Hyper? Emotional? All of these play a role in side effects of meds that go to the brain. There is nobody that is 'normal'. We are all different. Just because someone gets up in the middle of the night to drive, eat, or have sex without knowing it, is not something that should scare others into not taking it. The sex part does interest me however (smile). As with any drug, read the rather lengthy info packet that comes with it and discuss it with a pharmacist if you have concerns.

column2: waterslide, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This drug works really well and I would reccomend it... but beware and know that you likely will become dependent on it and eventually need to wean yourself off.  Highly addictive.  I used Ambien to sleep through my chronic pain.  It works best if taken on an empty stomach right before going to bed.  I had to wait up for 20 or 30 minutes before laying down to get the best effect.  I used it for many years and was very Dependant on it.  In the end it really took a toll on my memory.  I was not even able to read a book anymore.  I also started writing emails that I did not remember sending... things like that.  It took three months to wean myself off, but I did it.  I miss the deep sleep, but now my brain is working again!!  Reading books and communicating much better now :)To wean off, you will need the plain generic pills to chop in pieces. Taking 3/4 of the dose for 2 weeks then 1/2 a dose for several weeks and down to 1/4 of a pill.  Took me about 3 months to stop it.  I also had some Ativan or Valuim to help with the anxiety.  I still have to take an anti-anxiety pill to sleep but it does not have the "big" side effects that Ambien did.

column9: I am 62,female and have had insomnia for thirty years.Have been on generic Ambien 10 mgs for 15 years. The oblong Zolpidem 10 mgs dooesn't work as well as the round Zolpiem 10mgs. column2: RuthDV, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I've had a terrible sleep disorder for the past decade. Used Ambien in 2003, but our insurance co. quit covering it, so I had to resort to over-the-counter sleep aides, which DID NOT WORK for me! Last March I heard it had gone generic and I needed it badly, as I was diagnosed with bilateral breast-cancer a year ago this week. Sleep would have been impossible during the weeks and months of my biopsies/diagnoses/surgeries. Too much anxiety & heartache to deal with! The generic Ambien (Zolpidem) worked so well for me, I've stayed on it the entire year, with NO side-effects. I only take 5 mg. per night, and usually sleep all night now, unless I'm overly-anxious about something. I've tried NOT taking it a few times, but can't get to sleep ... and once I do finally drop off, I wake up at ANY little sound, and stay awake. (My husband snores LOUDLY, so the "little sounds" really aren't that little!) Ambien/Zolpidem has given me a new lease on life. We NEED our sleep to function in the day, and I am MUCH MORE functional with this medication.

column2: Momx3, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I was rx'd Ambien when I had some horrific insomnia as a result of contracting Lyme disease. Further, along with PMS I also have some occasional/transient insomnia  I don't have regular sleeplessness or an inability to fall asleep, however I AM a person who has always needed my 8 hours in order to function well. My doctor informed me of the side effects of somnambulism, gave me quite pointed and graphic examples of people who had experienced serious side effects, but I was willing to try it after only having slept about 3 hours in 3 days. I have found that 10 mg is the magic number for me after only getting about 4-5 hrs sleep on the 5 mg. I DO have some crazy dreams while on it, but I have very graphic, full-color light/sound/smell type dreams when I'm not taking it which not common to most people anyway, so I consider this a very mild side effect. Also, I don't wake up in a fog or too drowsy. A few things- you are NOT supposed to take this drug until you are READY FOR BED. I can't believe all the things I've read here from people who take this regularly and do completely irresponsible things like take it and then sit up and drink wine! Hello? This drug is a HYPNOTIC. It's not like downing Nyquil and getting drowsy. It lulls your brain quickly in to a sleep/dream state so you MUST take it, not should, when your PJs are on with the glass of water at your nightstand and your head on the pillow. It works very fast- 30 min or less on an empty stomach in my case. Second, if you're taking this EVERY day and you're losing your mind, depressed, has it not occurred to you or your doctor to try something else? See a sleep disorder specialist, change drugs, and most certainly get a new doctor.  Holy mother of science, there are SO many drugs on the market that there is no excuse to suffer. Take it AS DIRECTED and if it works for you, great. This drug is not for everyone, esp. people with underlying disorders like undiagnosed  or untreated depression. Read the packaging!!

column2: 75 or over Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver)
column9: Please BEWARE, people with ELDERLY loved ones. While this drug may work for a certain group of individuals, if you take it into your old age, it will turn on you. It wasn't until my Mom was put into assisted living that we discovered one of her medical problems. This drug she had taken for years without too many problems created complete psychosis when she developed mild demensia. She was not my Mom. It was awful. Her last time to take it, we had to call an ambulance and she cursed at me (something she'd never done in my life), & tried to pull out her IV among other things, until about 5:00am when the hospital flushed the Ambien out of her system. She then looked at me and said "honey why don't you go home-you look tired", and I realized my Mom had returned and the Ambien-induced psychosis was gone. The irony was she was taking Ambien for help sleeping and was exhausted all the time, yet she didn't remember being awake all night. And thank goodness, she never hurt herself before we could get her off of it. I don't think it's worth the risk. I would certainly advise Any elderly person I know to never take this drug.

column2: jfink, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: Started taking ambien about 3 months ago, I find I can't sleep without it. Oftentimes I'll look at my phone and find text messages I don't remember writing. Some in my drafts that weren't sent luckily. I haven't driven anywhere, nor have I eaten in my sleep (I think) but I know I text in my sleep without knowing it. I can't necessarily say this is deal breaking, I haven't slept this well in years, but I find that I need to have a better schedule with it, take it at the same time every night, and go to bed shortly after, empty stomach, and only one. I know that I've taken more than one before. I have only done it once or twice though, so I'm not terribly worried about that. Any alcohol what so ever though and it makes it ten times worse. Definitely do not drink when your taking this ever, definitely notice more intense side effects if I've had anything to drink. Definitely be careful with alcohol and any other drugs your taking.

column2: Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: After years of suffering form insomnia due to anxiety, PTSD and pain from many spine surgeries I was given a plethora of different drugs to try. I was definitely worse after being a guinea pig.When I finally went through a sleep study and tested with Ambien, I finally woke up not feeling like I ran a marathon all night. I was responsive and clear becasue I finally had some solid sleep!I did wake up after 3-4 hours and was finally treated with Ambien CR. I take one at bedtime 10-15 days a month and clonopin on the other nights. It is true there is a loss of inhibition (eating outside a diet during the night) but nothing remarkable. I've seen a lot worse-drunk people! Note: Take it as described. Do no add alcohol, additional tablets or other drugs and don't drive. Not so hard, people-remember, it's sleep medication! Note: the generic forms ARE NOT EVEN CLOSE to being as effective-don't waste your nights or money on them.

column2: 55-64 Female  (Caregiver)
column9: This is a VERY dangerous drug. I am convinced that this drug shortened my father-in-law's life.  He took it for about a year without problems--then suddenly he started hallucinating all night long.  Family members had to spend the night with him, he got so agitated, to make sure he wouldn't get out of bed and fall (he was elderly).  He would claim to see strangers in his house and would get very confused at night. He talked and yelled out all night long.  When the drug would wear off in the morning, he was fine and thinking clearly for the rest of the day.  We didn't figure out it was the Ambien causing this condition until it was too late. He insisted on taking this drug to help him sleep, and the problem kept getting worse. We finally had to admit him to the hospital--they had to sedate him there, and was knocked out for 2 days, then taken to a nursing home. He died a month later.  Since then, I have talked to several people who have felt this drug had altered their brains (or their relatives' brains).  After seeing first hand what Ambien did to my poor father-in-law, I would plead with everybody NOT to take this dangerous drug!!!

column2: anonymous, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Been taking Ambien (generic) for about 6 years due to lifelong insomnia problems. Started at 5-10 mg a few nights per week, then increased as insomnia wornsened. Weight gain, chronic back pain, and tons of job stress are probably factors, but no sleep vs. sleep meds seemed logical. Now, I have to take 15-20 mg to even get 3-4 hours of sleep, but found that 10 mg puts me to sleep, and another 5-10 during night does okay. This drug IS physically addicting in that your body builds up a tolerance, but Ive never had the wacky behaviors others describe (except for a buzz feeling if I dont lay down 20-30 minutes after taking). Those who find it expensive, get generic at Costco-super cheap. Ive tried almost all sleep/sedating meds, different therapies, and natural practices-only Ambien works. Sleep tests didnt show abnormalities, so consensus is its something with my neurotransmitters (brain chemicals), specifically gabba. Have taken Xanax or hydrocodone for anxiety/pain with Ambien, but hate the side effects of those combos, even though I sleep more. Hope this info helps, but everyone is different, so dont use my info in place of your doctors advice.

column2: Pit Bull Rescuer, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I have taken Ambien 10mg (never tried the 12.5) off and on for many years.  As sleeping aids go, I think that this is the best drug there is.  True, I have experienced many "sleep activities" which I have little or no memory of -- especially after having been on it for a longer period of time.  I felt that it "wasn't kicking in well;" and continued to putter around the house instead of going straight to bed, as directed.  I do not think that anyone would have these episodes if we all followed the directions to the letter as far as taking the medicine on an empty stomach; and going straight to bed with plans to go straight to sleep.  The medicine does not make me feel "high" at all.  I really cannot tell that I have taken it, as far as feelings go.  However, I obviously know it worked since I was asleep through at least 4 hours each night.  I disagree that one will have all these "withdrawal symptoms" if one abruptly stops the drug.  I have taken it for literally a whole year -- then stopped it suddenly.  The worst that happened was that a couple nights were fairly long and miserable due to lack of sleep.  There was no nausea, vomiting, shakiness, etc. as the warnings say.  This is not a benzodiazapine drug with dangers of seizures, etc. with abrupt withdrawal.  In fact, my OB-GYN says that she prescribes it to most of her pregnant patients to help them sleep!  I think that too much "hype" has been attributed to a fairly mild, but effective drug.  I highly recommend it. I have tried many others; as I have literally SUFFERED from lack of quality sleep over the years.  Nothing has really worked as well as Ambien for me.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: Been taking Ambien since my early 20's. Initially, gives you a feeling of being high, and once you put your head to the pillow, you fall right to sleep. Also has you do things you wouldn't normally do if you weren't on it...I would call people and talk total nonsense and not remember the conversation... slurred speech, desire to clean & organize things, dye my hair, try AND do stupid things I wouldn't normally do if I weren't on it...one day I decided to reorganize my whole bedroom in the middle of the night, even carrying the t.v. from one side of the room to the other, I coulda broke my back! Went to sleep with white socks on, woke up in the morning with black socks-didn't remember waking up and changing them. I also developed a tendency to binge eat AFTER taking it. It also causes short-term memory loss.  My mother, who was taking it at one point, walked up the block to my house, fixed the air conditioner, walked around the entire neighborhood, went back home...and remembered none of this the next day! I thought she knew exactly WHAT she was doing that night as she seemed fully awake and aware while she was at my house, but turns out she was blacked out during the entire time. She had taken 20mg of Ambien, and afterward went outside and did these things without even knowing.  Her husband accompanied her because she INSISTED on going out and rather than have her go out alone, he went with her cause she was leaving regardless.  My advice to those who have problems sleeping, try natural alternatives, if not, use Ambien short-term with physician supervision. Make sure everything at home is locked, off, and you're in bed when you take it. I'm about to take and Ambien shortly to go to sleep...but after taking it for so long it doesn't work as well.  Going to ask the doctor to try something else. Good luck to new users!

column2: Sleepyhead, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: Yes, your body will get used to the cozy warmth of Ambien sleep. To wean yourself from it is very simple. Wait till a weekend when you can sleep in the next day. Take a different, over the counter sleep aid like Tylenol PM. Take only half of one or you will be sleeping for two days.  And then get to bed. Don't sit around and watch TV until 2 a.m. You will not sleep as well, but you will sleep.  Keep sudden noises and light out of your room.  The next night, do the same. The last night (Sunday night), take nothing, or take just a plain Tylenol. You should now be weaned from Ambien.  If it doesn't work and you don't sleep enough on Sunday night, try it again the next weekend, and this time take the Tylenol PM two hours earlier each night than you did before and take two Tylenols on Sunday night and one on Monday night.I have kicked the Ambien habit at least twice, back in the day when my doctor wouldn't let me take it long-term, even though I was falling asleep at the wheel due to lack of sleep. My doctor now gives me 90 pills.  I ask for 10 mg and then snap them in half. 5 mg works just fine for me.  You don't build up a tolerance.  If it's not working for you, it's because you don't get into bed right after you take it. Don't fall asleep on the couch after taking Ambien, because when you finally get into bed, the sleepiness and cozy edge will have worn off and you will end up waiting a little longer to sleep.

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Serious withdrawal is unlikely with this drug, but if you are one of the lucky ones it does strike please know that it generally last months, and tends to be worse then the withdrawal from heroin or cocaine. Symptoms can include seizures, depression, anxiety attacks, psychosis, nausea, and more. Also, please know that even if you only take the medicine as directed and as proscribed by your doctor you are still running a risk of withdrawal. Just because you don't feel addicted does not mean you are not physically dependent on it. I always thought I was safe because I didn't crave the drug, didn't want to take more then I was proscribed, didn't doctor shop, and didn't drink with it. I wasn't addicted, but my body was dependent. I have lost months of my life to this drug, so please be careful with it.

column2: seattlegradschoolbabe, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: It's simple: If you have an addictive personality, don't take this drug. However, if you're a normal person with reasonable self-control and a healthy respect for the potential dangers of prescription drugs, and are able to adhere to label instructions, it's highly likely you'll be fine. I'm a grad student that occasionally has trouble sleeping, often because I had caffeine too late in the day. Ambien puts me right to sleep and I sleep till morning. I only take it on nights where I lie in bed awake for an hour or so and still can't fall asleep. If you practice self-control and only take it when you NEED it, it's very unlikely you'll become addicted. I was first prescribed it in July of 2008 and have gone through maybe 60 pills since then. Breaking them in half and only taking 5 mg usually works for me. Have never done anything crazy like eat, drive, or have conversations while asleep, but then I always take it while already in bed, like the directions say!! It works for me, and doesn't make me groggy at all the next day like Phenegran or even Tylenol PM does. If you are unable to follow instructions for potentially dangerous drugs, then don't take this drug or any other potentially dangerous drugs. If you're a responsible adult that can control him or herself then you should be fine. And TELL your doctor if you get addicted, for crying out loud!!! They can't help you if they don't know what's going on.

column2: caregiver, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver)
column9: My father was 86 yrs old when he passed away last October. Two years earlier he was prescribed Ambien for sleep problems and became dependent on Ambien. We tried telling him that since he was older he didn't require 10-12 hrs of sleep. Yet when he would wake up he wanted more Ambien to sleep another 10-12 hrs. He grew very depressed, anxious and anorexic and grew very angry when we would prolong giving him the Ambien. The last year of his life Ambien wasn't working anymore, with 20 mg. he was up all night reaching for things that weren't there, eating and chattering about things that didn't make sense. Although we reported it to his md, he said it would do my father more harm than good to take him off the Ambien. It was my mother and sometimes myself that were not getting a good night's sleep because we had to keep watch over him. He experienced 2 falls and ended up at the ER because of Ambien.

column9: have had no side effects, but you can increase your chance of it working, and cutting down your dosing (saving money by using less - but small print: talk to your doc): 1) it has a VERY short half life so you wake up clear headed and no groggy 'hang over' so be READY for it, for me that window is almost exactly 20 min. and lasts about 10 min. After that the effectiveness of the drug falls off makeing it less effective, so if I'm watching TV, I take it about 10 minutes before I stop, and then turn on Radio BBC so I'm settled in bed for 10 minutes and relaxing before I know Ambian will peak in my blood.  2) You can use an herbal drug, Melatonin.  Take the Melatonin about 30 minutes before you take the Ambian. This will allow you to use less because your body is more receptive to accepting the Ambian. You can check this by using PubMed, a search engine for National Institutes of Health, National Library of Medicine.3) If you drink it with just a small glass of grapefruit juice, the Grapefruit juice seems to boost the potency of many of these kinds of drugs.  To help protect your teeth from what is called 'juice teeth' -- tooth decay caused by the acidity in citrus juices and the bacteria which eat the sugar found in all fruit juices, and produce various acids which attack many parts of your teeth, especially the enamel that protects your teeth.So, 1) take some Melatonin about 30 min. before the Ambian. This makes your body more receptive to Ambian. (2 MS's in Bio. Sciences makes me know this is not 'hippie medicine, that it has research showing it's true).2) make sure you have lights off, head on pillow 10 min. before the Ambian is going to be in high enough blood concentration to work, and 3) drink a small glass of Grapefruit juice, as this will increase it's ability to work. Rinse your mouth with baking soda (Bi carb of soda [not powder], Arm and Hammer is a brand name) 1 tsp in 1 cup water, and spit it out, this protects your teeth from acid and bacteria.

column2: seabeancmf, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I cannot express enough the danger of taking Ambien. While it worked very well for me for quite some time, the last time I took it, I woke up the next day in the hospital. I had taken it the previous night, fallen to sleep, I had gotten up, got into my car, driven off, and rear-ended a car stopped at a stop light, all the time completely unconscious and unaware. I hit my head on the windshield (yes, I had my seat belt on)and completely shattered it and even that didn't wake me up. I was taken to the hospital by ambulance and kept there for 5 days because I was disoriented from a concussion. All this and I had only taken one pill, as prescribed. I also had a traffic ticket mailed to me for careless driving. I had spoken to the police, and had given incorrect information in the emergency room, and spoken with nurses and doctors without waking up until the next afternoon. Please take this as a warning- this whole episode happened without my having had any problems prior to that night. I believe this could have happened to anyone and probably has. So BEWARE!

Tylenol, Advil, and Alleve did not help. I went to my optomotrist for evaluation but he found nothing wrong with my eyes. No dryness, no high intraocular pressure. My vision prescription only changed slightly in 5 years. All this time I am taking Ambien but now the eye pain is not going away at night. My nephew who is working on his masters in sleep disorders was visiting and I was telling him how great Ambien worked and mentioned my eye pain. He said Ambien was not supposed to be prescribed for long term use and suggested I stop taking it for a while. Bottom line is I stopped taking the Ambien and within a week the eye pain went away.

column9: I have never had problems sleeping besides the occassional problem "winding" down after a busy day.  Then I had gastric bypass surgery and started to experience sleeplessness that I attributed to stress on the job.  After a doctor's visit I started taking Ambien CR which was very expensive, even with my insurance, so I tried to take the non-extended release because it is a cheaper generic and could only sleep about 4 hours and then I was fully awake.  After taking Ambien CR for more than a year and initially experiencing no side effects I have routinely been eating afterwards and get out of bed to find food and have no memories of it the next day except for the missing food, wrappers in the trash, and crumbs in the bed the next morning.  I tried to stop taking the drug after running out of it and could not sleep even through other methods - alcohol, pain medicine, and muscle relaxers.  Although I wish that my doctor had only prescribed the drug for the short term, I feel that I may be dependent on it.  After experiencing weight gain, some insomnia, and worsening episodes of nightime eating I am going to try and "kick the habbit" with all of the knowledge of how to make yourself sleep, excersize after dinner, only go to bed to sleep, no TV watching in bed, and make a cool and dark bedroom conducive to sleeping.  After trying this I will repost to this site.  Wish me luck.

column2: rm431, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: If u have trouble with ambien, then try ambien-CR instead. I was on the generic ambien. Worked for a short while, then I started having issues not sleeping very long, or if I failed to take it then I was totally unable to sleep. Like a caffeine high. My doc switched to the ambien-CR. The CR type is a lot more costly cause no generic for the CR. BUT... the ambien-CR is A LOT more effective, gentle, and not addictive. You can go on - off it and not get messed up. I can get to sleep without it. But I only take ambien when I MUST get good sleep. The CR type is much more user-friendly. And you will not wake after 2 or 3 hours, tossing and turning like I did on the non-CR type.I work nights and sleep days, so that is why I need it, to get good sleep on my screwed up schedule. Ambien-CR works! The non-CR type DID NOT. There is a difference, a big difference, between the two types.

column2: snowkitty, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This is the second time in my life i've been prescribed ambien. The 1st time i was in high school and couldn't sleep, i would go days and only sleep an hour or two. I started out on 10mg and it worked wonders. I took it everynight about 20 mins before i was ready to go to bed. I would actually get a full 7-8 hrs of restfull sleep. Never had any problems w/most side effects, even when i came off the drug when i found out i was pregnate. However the 1st time i was on it i was young and unmarried. My daughter is five now and i have been put back on Ambien several months ago. I've always had trouble sleeping and have always been a very light sleeper, so light that my husband (someone i'm comfortable with) can walk into the room, silent as can be, and his just the "feel" of him being in the room wakes me. I'm not on 5mg as needed. I find that i have to take it during the work week or else it will be 1-2 am when i finally fall asleep. Which does not work well for me as i go to bed by 9:30 and am up by 5:20 & i still wake up several times. The 5mg works well in putting me to sleep but since being on it for a few mths i find that i still wake up at least once through the night. When i go to see my Dr i will talk about taking the 10mg dose as it worked very well for me for years. My husband says that while on it i talk in my sleep and i will answer anything he asks me. Its a good thing i have nothing to hide b/c i would never have known about this if he hadn't have told me. I have had no other side effect tho, defenitly no sleep walking, eating or driving. I know many people who it doesn't work for and who have had hallucinations but it works wonders for me. It's definetly something worth trying but should be watched closely in the beginning. Oh & my 5 yr old daughter has no trouble what so ever waking me up at anytime of the night while on the drug. I generally don't take it on the weekend having no work schedule to adhere to & have no problems not taking it regularly.

column2: J, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: Perhaps a bit pessimistic, yet my review stands because I had a severe reaction. 10mg and 38hrs as I write this, I am still having residual symptoms.  I can't concentrate.  My eyes are unfocused.  Memory loss and incoherence.  Blackouts. I fell into the bath tub, not out of it. No water in the tub.  Sleep deprivation. Rapid pulse, racing feeling.  Eating and talking rapidly. Feeling like I am losing my mind.  I feel the urge to scream.  Anger.  Nervousness.  That's just to name the surface.  I called my Doctor and she took me off it.  I was on Trazadone.  I have a chronic nervoous condition as I am a disabled veteran. Plus I have sleep apnea.  I am glad this med works for those who can take it.  For me, it was like a very bad LSD trip.  I will never take it again, not even in a reduced amount.

column2: DWitty, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I have been taking the generic version (Zolpidem Tartrate) of Ambien (10mg) since mid Feb.  I works as advertised since I suffered from a condition called "advanced sleep syndorone", where my body's timeclock was off kilter.  I'd get sleepy around 6:30PM, and awaken around 2AM every night.  End up sluggish with diminished focus beginning around noon.  Ambien worked by putting my sleep routin back into a natural rhythm.  Side Effects: extreme itching and rashes, causing me to come off of it for certain periods. No weird dreams/nightmares, and not odd behavior whil on it

column2: lally, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: My daughter was prescribed this med for a chronic sleep problem she's had since she was a kid. The police called our house one morning looking for my daughter, saying she had been involved in a hit and run accident the previous night. We tried to call her but there was no answer at her apartment.  After a frantic drive to find out what happened, we arrived at her place to find her car parked outside wrecked with 2 flat tires.  We finally were able to awaken her and when she saw the car, she was shocked---she had no recollection of anything the previous night.  Luckily no bodily harm, but we did need to find an attorney to help us deal with the charges.  What a nightmare!  Please do not take this drug unless you absolutely cannot find any other sleep remedy and have a person who can babysit you the entire time!!!

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

I slept well, arose at 5:15am, took a shower, had a conversation with my husband and left the house for an appointment at 6am.  I remember driving about 1/2 mile away from home, on a neighborhood street and the next thing I remember is sitting in my car with the air bag deployed and people around me, including a fire truck and ambulance.  I had run into 2 parked cars.  I have no memory of this.  I was taken to the hospital by ambulance where I was checked, including low blood sugar, stroke, heart attack, etc.  All tests were negative.  Subsequently I saw a neurologist and had an MRI and EEG to rule out seizure disorder, which they did.  Even though it was 9 hours after taking the Ambien, the doctors could not attribute my accident to anything else.

[I confess to using a rather large glass] I take the ambien with extreme caution, as I sit on the bed. Some times it works, and some times not. I will toss and turn for hours, even with the pill. But when it works, it's for almost exactly four hours. I wake up, look at the clock--yep, four hours, then finally doze off. At 70, I really don't fear addiction--I don't care. But I just wish they would work, and work all night. I know that losing my wife of 40 years is a major part of my problem, but there is nothing I can do about that. Grief counseling is comforting, but no real help.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Caregiver)
column9: I have been using Ambien since 1999, after my Dr put mu on an antidepressant (Prozac)  and was going on 4-5 days at a time without sleep.  After a few weeks on Ambien my Dr wanted to ween me off to see if my insomnia improved and it didn't we tried various other antidepressants at various doses, I went on a sleep study, went to a psychologist,etc with no help.  So I have been diagnosed with chronic insomnia.  I have been on the 10 mg dose but at times it does not work like if I am under stress.  (I am in nursing school and I have more problems right before major exams etc.) So My Dr and I  have decided to up my dose, I take 1 -1.5 tablets normally which still works and 2 tablets max.  I like the fact that this drug has a very short half life 2 -2.5 hrs.  This meas after 2 hrs half of the drug has been excreted and at 4 hrs 75% is out of the system etc.  Which means even if I was up studying till 2 or 3 in the morning and have a 8 AM class I can still take the medicine and wake up pretty refreshed. I have not experienced the sleep walking or any other of the side effects even after 10 yrs.  As I will be a RN in 5 months I feel this is a pretty safe and effective drug. Yes there is the risk of physical dependency, but not addiction, and yes there is a difference.  I have had times before this drug had a generic form and was $120.00 a month that I could not afford to get it and things like Benadryl did nothing.  I never had the urge to "get a fix" or steal or what ever just to get my Ambien,  I did without sleep until I could afford it which was miserable at times.   As with all medications work with your Dr, and take it the way they say is safe and if you have bad side effects or allergic reactions stop and get help.

column2: Lee, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I started having trouble sleeping when my parents (who live 500 miles away) health started to fail.  I took OTC doxylamine at low doses (12.5 mg/night) for a while. But it made me loggy and also caused bladder problems (It felt like I'd go in to urinate on tuesday afternoon and not come out until thursday morning..)  So, I wanted to find an alternative. About the same time, I was diagnosed with early prostate cancer and was scheduled for surgery. Now, I REALLY had trouble sleeping. So, my GP gave me generic Zolpidem 10mg (Ambien).  I took it pretty regularly through my surgery (which was successful) and after about 7 months of regular use, I was ready to stop and go back to the occasional antihistamine for sleep  (doxylamine).  But you don't just quit Zolpidem like flipping a light switch. At least I couldn't.  I got major insomnia as well as chest crushing anxiety and shortness of breath. So, I'm in the process of tapering now with the help of Remeron which causes quite a bit of somulence.I'm down to a half a zolpidem (5mg)every 3rd night and plan to be off it completely in another 3-4 weeks.  So...  for me the bottom line on this stuff is that it is a great SHORT TERM insomnia remedy.  It knocks you out clean for 7-8 hours and you wake up chipper (at least I did). But it is a short half-life drug and it acts on the same receptors as the benzos like valium and xanax. If you are on it for very long, it can have a nasty hook and you may have to taper gradually to avoid some pretty nasty withdrawals. It's a very good and effective sleep aid, but I don't think any MD should write a script for longer than say a month, max and even that may be too long for some folks, in particular people who are in alcohol or drug recovery (as I am with 10 1/2 years sober).  Good stuff, but watch the duration of use. That's my view, anyway..

25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver)
column9: This medicine works very well, Yet only if it is used as perscribed!. I've had problems sleeping for about a decade and have tried out other methods and this drug works the best. YET,(some advice for the people who can't afford under the counter treatment) I find it very similar to over the counter sleep aids like unisom,Simply Sleep or the knock off brands that contain the same chemical. I've known of certain people who take this Ambien as a means to get high, and I can see why they do. It reacts to the body as if almost like a benzodiazepam- aka Valium,Klonopin and xanax in the fact that it delivers a very calming and warm feeling within 45 minutes of taking it. When people report being very "Chatty" and motivated that is the drug taking over your mind because you are in a warm and calm state. Take for instance when a DR. prescribes Xanax to a person who has social Anxiety, what happens? that person becomes more socialiable to his or her peers.Well the same thing happens while taking Ambien. The more calm people get, the more often they tend to let their guard down and engage in conversations that in a sober state of mind they normally wouldn't. So if you are prescribed this drug take it while you are actually in bed and turn off the T.V. or anything that u THINK will kill the time before the drug kicks in. Also make sure your kids or loved ones are also in the process of "going to bed" and try to avoid any potential distractionss of any kind while on this medication... My knowledge of this drug is based on experience and of practice.

column9: DANGEROUS, SELF HARMING, & NOT WORTH THE RISK OF SIDE EFFECTS!!!I have had many a sleepless night since the recent death of my grandmother & it has gotten worse since my grandfather is ill & passing also. I became Aggitated, Aggressive, violent & belidgerant all at once. I have no memory of a 6 hour span. Thank God I was home with my sisters & neice. With their watchful eyes & amazing control, they prevented me from self harm with kitchen knives, driving my car,  & falling over the porch railing!! I even tried to smoke a plastic straw & I don't even smoke!!! Not to mention trying to clean out the medicine cabinet with old, expired meds & possibly taking them!! Lastly, I tried to wash sheets & make the bed again with my sister in-law still in the bed! My family debated on calling 911 & rushing me to the hospital to have my stomach pumped. column2: los angeles,ca woman, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: HAVE HAD SEVERE STOMAch PROBLEMS(DIVIRTiculitis),asthma,pressure in my chest(angina).was suffering alot with pain and discomfort and rheumatoid arthritis.my pain med was not helping but ambien sure helps me get the rest that my body needs so i can have a better day.you need to give yourself time to sleep or dont take it until you get time.take it eve7 or 8pm with no food in belly stay in bed,turn everything off then you can sleep till 8 or 9 pm next day. atleasr plan to allow time for 12 hrs of sleep. eat earlyby 5 or 6pm to get ready to sleep at 7pm, brush your teeth and urinate then take your pill and relax in bed with a book or tv for a few minutes then ambien will kick in and you will sleep until the following morning.sleeping enough is the key to not feeling groggy the next day. go to bed early to be able to sleep more , if you have to work then also plan on 10 to 12 hrs or more if possible for your sleep and if you dont work than sleep as much as you feel you need wake up when you feel rested.  that is the problem that people want to take ambien but they dont have the time they need to sleep. please only take it if you are allowing 12 hrs at least for your sleep or please dont take you wont feel your rested when you wake up. i repeated this so it could be understood that the side affects can be few to none.

column9: Zolpidem Tartrate ("Ambien") has greatly helped me.  Since childhood, I have suffered from chronic insomnia and have only been able to feel "normal" since using this prescription medicine.  I no longer feel ill from lack of sleep day after day. I no longer am a hazard on the road because of "seeing double" from lack of sleep as I drive to work.  I am able to get up at a normal time (6-7 a.m. on work days) and feel happy and healthy all day long.  I no longer lie in bed waiting to go to sleep until 4 a.m. only to have to wake up at 6.  Sleep deprivation - as a result of some type of organic (no stimulants ever!) insomnia has been very difficult to endure until now.  I am a teacher with many responsibilites, and I know that this prescription has improved my mental state; my memory and other mental processes function better than ever!  The stress of "bad sleep" has been eliminated.  I'm very grateful for this medicine as it has helped to improve the quality of my life and allowed me to get the rest I need.  Thank you.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have had trouble sleeping my entire life, but when my husband was diagnosed with cancer, and we had to file bankruptcy, it became much worse. I was taking the 5mg dose at first, when it wasn't as effective, I moved up to the 12.5 mg dose. I was so excited to finally be getting some sleep, I started taking Ambien every single night. I never got up and ate without knowing it, but it did make me hungry during the day. I gained 10 lbs quickly. But the worst side effect: major depression. I was already stressed enough, but starting feeling suicidal after taking Ambien for over a month. I had never heard of this happening with Ambien, so I thought it was simply everything else going on. I decided to stop taking Ambien, and quit cold turkey. Within two days, I felt more normal, and didn't have the deep depression I was experiencing. I will never take Ambien on a regular basis again, it was scary how depressed and angry I got. I know this doesn't happen with everyone, but I want people to know that it CAN happen in certain situations, and to be careful taking this drug. I would rather not sleep than experience what I did with Ambien.

column2: jadamen, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)

Sometimes I just get up and walk around the house or do little chores. column9: I had been taking Ambien off and on for 3 years.  In the beginning it was very effective but I used it sporadically because I had a newborn to take care of. I also was informed of crazy and embarassing things I talked about with my teenage son (I was looking for Moose and I was very happy that I had my very own pony). I also became agitated with him that he would not give me candy, so I must have gotten up and found some Skittles and shoved the hole bag in my mouth so much that I do remember not being able to close my mouth. I woke up the next morning hoping that what I did remember was a dream, only to get up and hear several Skittles hit the floor.  I would only use this medication when someone is there to supervise you in case something like this happens.  I did stop taking it because I really did not like the memory loss and that I wasn't in control of what I said or ate.

column2: kiss, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
USAFSGT, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: Quality sleep is highly underrated. In the past 15 years I have had a fair amount of difficulty getting and staying asleep. Because of my years of sleep deprivation my doc started me off on 20mgs of Ambien nightly. I experienced what I called "noxious, nocturnal, noshing". I was making several trips in a daze to the fridge. This was evidenced by containers of melted sherbert, open jars of peanut butter and crackers, and half eaten fruit I would discover in the morning. My shape was rapidly becoming round. Without consulting my doctor I switched to 10 mg of Ambien with 2 mg lorazepam. It worked wonders insofar as I get to sleep within 30-45 minutes of medicating. Only problem is staying asleep and I am going to see if the VA carries Ambien CR as the secondary release of the medication might allow me to remain asleep. I think everyone needs to find their individual tolerance for this and all other medications. I used to take valium for muscle spasms with the bonus effect of drowsiness. It has an unacceptably long half life so it was not a good medication for me. I have made peace with the nocturnal noshing and no longer keep sherbert and other calorie dense items in my house.

column2: artist1234, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: This is a drug to be wary of...let me tell you why.  I began taking Ambien about a year ago, but only took it when I knew I would have trouble sleeping - like the night before a job interview and such.  It seemed to work great.  After a while, I found myself taking it more often.  It happened slowly and I didn't realize for a while how dependent I had become.  Eventually, I was taking it almost every night. Over the past year, I have also begun to deal with some extreme emotional ups and downs and felt depressed, very depressed at times.  I didn't make a connection.  However, as I have begun to wean myself off of the drug for the past month (down to 1/4 tablet once or twice a week),it feels like a veil is lifting.  Not only do I feel much stronger, but my thinking is becoming sharper again. I am no doctor, but after listening to my own body, I have decided that this is a drug that DOES affect your brain functions and should be taken with great awareness of how it may be changing your thoughts.  Has anyone else experienced a connection to depression?

column2: dkf, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: I suffer from severe insomnia and this medication has been the only one I get any sleep with.  I tried several other prescriptions before Ambien, I take the 12.5 CR version, and it makes a world of difference.  I would say at least 85% of the time I cannot fall asleep on my own and if I do, I never stay asleep for more than an hour.  Ambien provides a full nights rest.  There are side effects, minimal in my opinion, but for me almost anything is better than not sleeping.  I experience a quite hightened sense of hunger about 30 mins after I take it.  Also, I usually cannot recall my actions from about an hour after I take it to the time I go to sleep the next day. I also have seen a marked decrease in my ability to remember things.  Not so bad as to where I would discontinue use, but that only my opinion.  For people with SEVERE insomnia I would highly recommend this medication, if your situation is only mild to moderate I would suggest exhausting all other options first, it's always nice to avoid side effects when possible.

column2: LiteCol, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I began with this drug 10 or 12 years ago, taking .5 mg for the first few years, then 10 mg for the last many years. During part of this time, I lived alone.  Ambien had such an amnesic effect on me that I would awake many mornings to find upon entering the kitchen that I had gotten up, cooked a full meal, and eaten it.  Even then I had no memory, and I would examine the cookware to see what I had cooked and eaten.  Usually, it was a big, full meal. Ambien caused me to be very hungry, and it had the amnesic effect. So why did I take it for so long? It WORKED!  With it, I was able to sleep despite my back pain. I found nothing else strong enough.  Why did I quit Ambien? Because during my amnesic state, I became ugly (not abusive) to my wife.  I spoke to her angrily, and I was very obstinate, I am told. So I weaned myself off Ambien over a two-week period and had no problems with withdrawal, neither physical nor psychological.  I just could not sleep.  I am retired, and I was accustomed to getting (with Ambien) about 10 hours per night.  That changed from 10 to as little as one and a half hours per night, but usually more like four to six hours, so that I hae a continuous sleep deficit which dulls me during the day.  Than at night, I cannot sleep.  Because the insomnia has gotten so bad, I am about to go back on some sleeping aid, maybe Ambien. Overall, I was happy with Ambien because it worked, but the  amnesia and becoming unlike myself and ugly to my wife really took a lot out of me.

column9: Scary Scary Scary!  I would take this drug to help with my insomnia.  However I never would sleep.  I'd end up in a weird 1/2 sleep state where i didnt remember anything the next day.  Id eat 1/2 of what was in my kitchen and not remember, i'd actually eat something finish it and not remember five minutes later so I'd go and get something to eat  again not knowing ive been eating.  I even tried to drive once, backing up into my mailbox not even remembering it the next day.  I was talking and interacting with my boyfriend fine, he was even in the car but i have no knowledge of this.  In fact we live together and at times we'd talk and 10 minutes later we talk again and i wouldnt remember the last convrsation.  He did not know what was wrong with me.  This happened for about 5 days straight.  I kept taking the medication because I actually thought i was sleeping on it! He didn't know i was on medication but the more continuous odd nights in a row and the worsening of the nights put him at alarm. He finally ended up recording me the last night thats how i even realised that i wasnt sleeping after all and this drug was having potentially serious side effects.  Just take with caution b4 you know how you react to this medication. Also let someone know that you are trying an new medication and the things they should be aware of.  Such as excessive eating, Saying something that doesn't make sense then kinda snapping out of it.(like you are 1/2 asleep but seem totally awake!)

After and emergancy room visit the Dr gave me antibotics and a nasal spray to help with the pain in my face.  Nothing would relieve the pain. Until i decided to discontinue the ambien just to see. Ambient was the only new medication i had added to the daily meds that i take.  I have been off the ambien for 3 nights now.  The feeling in my head diminished immediately I feel so much better.  I feel like im detoxing myself, but the change is remarkable.  I dont think i will be taking anymore ambien. i will try the otc advil or tylenol pm meds..

column2: subee, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
curtx29, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: In order for this medication to work the best, I take it and immediately go to bed.  It takes effect very quickly (within 15 mins) and if I'm in bed, I'll fall asleep easily every time.  If I stay up, it is somewhat euphoric and would be fun for an addict, but don't plan on sleeping well -- there seems to be a 15 to 45 min window where you can go to sleep.  There is very little tossing and turning and when I wake up, I feel rested about 75% of the time.  The only middle-of-the-night side effect I've noticed is a case of the munchies (you'll want to stop by the fridge on your way back from the bathroom and eat cereal, chocolate, etc.).  Sometimes I'll wake up after only 5 or 6 hrs of sleep, which is ok because my body is rested, but at 5 AM there's nothing to do.  Have mild fatigue/headache the next morning about 2 out of 7 days and it goes away by mid-day.

column2: tucker0402, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I was on Ambien (and then generic) for almost 5 years. During that time I experienced hallucinations and MANY memory loss situations; often I would call/text people and say emberassing things in the messages...things I had thought while not on the drug, but would never want to say to someone.  Eventually, I did become tolerant to the drug (even though they claim to be non-habit-forming) and found myself taking more and more, or having a glass of wine before taking one (to increase the effectiveness)...although at the time I would have NEVER admitted I was addicted.  The nights I wouldn't have one, I couldn't sleep.  Finally one night I was upset over work and a fight with my boyfriend, so I took two 10mg pills "so I could get a good nights' sleep"  The next thing I remember, I woke up in the ER with my best friend (and roomate) telling me she had to call the ambulance because I took an entire bottle of extra strength tylenol, the rest of the Ambien (nearly-new bottle), and other over-the-counter meds we had in the house.  I was in the ICU for 48 hours because the doctors couldn't get my heart rate regulated from all the medications in me.  I had NO intentions of suicide nor have I ever been "at risk" for doing something like that...I just couldn't sleep!  I hope this drug is pulled from the market immediately because it IS addictive and it has SERIOUS side-effects that are potentially life-threatening.  Do not take, nor let loved ones take, this drug!

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: This is the only sleep medication that works for me. I take 10mg, but it is only effective 2-3 times a week, with breaks in between. Because I had issues with memory loss and doing odd things while on it, I have to make sure I go to bed immediately and do not allow myself to get up. Sometimes I still get up and find myself having sent odd text messages throughout the night, which I have no memory of. It can put me to sleep like a baby if I take it and hop in bed, but if I take it and continue to stay up doing things, I will not find myself tiring, only acting strange.Also, this drug is addictive. I've found myself a bit addicted to the stoned feeling I have on it, and the fact that when I sleep while taking it I never remember my dreams.  (Every other morning I wake up with strange dreams from the night before and a headache. If another drug doesn't work for me, I will go to a sleep lab.)Overall, it's extremely effective... But there are many precautions I suggest taking while on it.

column2: WARNOCK80, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I started taking this medication when my husband and I were having problems and I couldn't sleep at all at night.  The first night I took it I took 5mg and I ended up ordering a lot of stuff online but couldn't fall asleep. The second night I decided to take the full 10mgs in hopes of going to sleep because by then it was well after 3am. My poor hubby had to work at 8 the next morning. After I took the pill and it had a chance to kick in I was started seeing black shadowy figures in my room. I told him to turn our clock radio on because they wanted to dance. Because he had to work he refused. After awhile of fighting over it because the "people" would get mad...I started singing at the top of my lungs at 4am so they could dance.  I remember it, but it was like a dream. Plus it made me more willing...I eventually got to sleep, but the hallucinations were insane.  My brother had the same problem with the hallucinations and a friend of mine was getting up in the middle of the night and driving to the stores and buying $100's of waffles, candy, and ice cream and wouldn't remember it, but would find it sitting on her kitchen counter when she woke up the next morning. Word of advice, if you do take it, hide your car keys and credit cards and make sure there is someone there to keep you from doing something you shouldn't. You could end up bankrupt. And watch for the hallucinations. They don't say much about those when you get the drug. Eventually though it helped with the sleeping....just had the other problems.

He wanted to kill me, as he has to be up @ 5:30 a.m.!!I would have no memory of it!! He didnt believe the fact that I couldnt remember! I would also fall asleep on the toilet!! column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I have always had trouble getting to sleep and staying asleep.  This drug worked wonders for me, and I never felt groggy the next day like I do with Trazodone.With 10mg I found that I was doing things I didn't remember the next day, but not so much with 5mg.  The 5mg still worked fine so I stayed with 5mg.  Better to take this before going to bed so you go to sleep otherwise it is more likely you'll have short term memory loss / doing strange things.Another poster said this drug is like a truth serum, and I agree.  It really makes you turn off the part of your brain that controls whether you should or should not do something.  I accidentally broke up with my girlfriend when she called me and woke me up in the middle of the night.  We were having some problems that I probably should have tried to work through, but I went straight for what was on my mind instead.  Another poster said they would wake up in the middle of the night and eat food, and i've done that too although I never ended up with a weight problem.Don't drive or anything like this when on this drug.  On 10mg sometimes I would lose my balance - another reason to use smaller doses if possible.Having said all of this, this drug worked the best for me.  I've tried for a few years to get on a better sleep cycle using natural methods with only modest success.  I worry about taking drugs for long periods so I am still trying natural methods.

column9: I've taken Ambien as needed for several months. It works great, puts me to sleep quickly and keeps me asleep for 6 hours. You do need to take it when you are going to bed. column2: KB, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have had sleep problems for years and the Ambien has really helped me. I take 5mg and usually fall asleep within 1/2 hour. I have about 4-5 hours of good sleep, then I'll sit right up and feel wide awake. Usually I can fall back asleep. I just wish the Ambien lasted longer. Do not drink any alcohol at all if you know your gonna take ambien that night. I would recommend you not take it until your already in bed. Don't get up again unless you really have to. I've taken it and then gotten back up and find myself banging into walls, and feeling very disorientated, almost drunk. I've occasionally had double vision while watching tv in bed. Alcohol can make you have really weird side effects so definitely don't drink at all if your gonna be taking this med. I had one experience where I drank one wine cooler around 9pm. I took an Ambien hours later, after midnight, and was acting very weird(according to my husband and sister). I was laughing over everything, and having odd conversations with my sister and husband that I barely remember. I couldn't stand without feeling like I was swaying back and forth. I was banging into everything, and felt almost like I was dreaming. Everything seemed like it was in slow motion. They told me I was standing in the mirror giving myself crazy hair dos and laughing at myself. I made some onion dip that I didn't eat and dropped pretzels all over the floor, made a huge mess. Very out of character for me. This only happened once and I believe it was the alcohol in my system, mixed with the med. Overall, the Ambien has worked great for me. Just take it as directed, don't drink alcohol, and stay in bed. I haven't had any side effects like trying to drive or shopping online with no memory like some of these other people. If only it lasted longer, it truly would be the greatest sleep med ever created. If your having sleep problems, I would definitely recommend this.

column9: My mother-in-law took Ambien for few years and was conerned about waking in the middle of the night,going down to the kitchen and eating. column9: Ok frist let me say that this is a very dangerous drug. no matter how you say you won't abuse it you do, but I can tell you frist hand this drug is VERY addictive, but only in your mind not your body like cocaine or herion would be. to get off this and I  TOTALY think anyone useing it should you will suffer several VERY MISERABLE nights but once your mind knows that you can rest or sleep without the pill you will find that you can sleep again and not worry about where you will "wake up" I drove while I was in a "awake state" and "woke up" two states away no idea how I got there, had conversations and sent e-mails I don't remember. column2: HipChick1961, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I've been taking Ambien for about 5 yrs. for chronic insomnia and night terror/nightmares. It has been a lifesaver for me but it IS a tricky drug. Take it when you are actually ready to go to sleep and you are already IN BED. Don't get back up!!! or you will be walking around the house eating, having weird conversations with your significant other about things that you would probably not be talking about if you were actually aware of what you were saying. Ambien makes you really chatty! If I take it and don't go right to bed, I can override the window of opportunity to get to sleep and then Im just awake and weird. Also, hide your car keys or you may find yourself on a road trip in your nightgown. Seriously, just tie yourself to the bed with some duck tape on your mouth. OK, really seriously, its a great drug that WILL help you get to sleep fast, and gives me about 3 to 4 hours good deep sleep with no nightmares...but then most nights I'm awake again and need to take another one to sleep the rest of the night. I've found that I can take a 10mg pill and break it in half to get to sleep initially, and then if I wake up wide awake 3 or 4 hours later, I take the other 1/2. When the alarm goes off in the morning I'm not groggy and feel rested. Also, with 1/2 a 10mg pill, I will wake up if I hear something that I need to wake up for. With a whole 10mg pill, I'm out pretty hard. It does come in a 5mg dose, but I like the choice of sleeping harder or lighter, and its cheaper to split the pills. Unless you wander around without awarness after taking Ambien, it is a great drug to help you get to sleep fast and at least for me, with no nightmares.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months
column9: My doctor prescribed three medications for me on my last physical (12/13/07).  I had complaints of trouble sleeping, anxiety, mild depression. I felt I was experiencing menopausal symtoms.  She diagnosed me as such and prescribed Ambien, Zoloft and Xanax. I was previously on no medications.  I filled the scripts that day and took one of each medication before bed - Ambien 10mg; Zoloft 50 mg; and Xanax .25 mg.  The next morning, I awoke to my kitchen in shambles.  Dishes and pots on the counters, Red Hot Sauce smeared on the kitchen floor and cupboards, and a broken refrigerator shelf.  I had absolutely no recollection of whatever I did that night, and it frightened me as if someone (not me) broke into my place and made this mess.  Of course, I knew it was me.  I felt ashamed and confused for many days after that incident.  I feel my doctor should have given me proper instruction on taking these drugs and the possible effects of taking them together at one time.  I feel the Ambien gave me the "crazy kitchen frenzy" and have not taken it since.  I do, however, continue to take the Zoloft (gaining weight), and only ocassionaly take the Xanax at night which helps me sleep.  Be careful with Ambien.

column9: I have trouble falling asleep; 5 mg of Ambien didn't help so my DR increased the dose to 10 mg. I was told by friends that I had called; packages arrived at my home -- SURPRISE!!! along with bills; and most frightening, I found all my medication bottles lined up on the kitchen counter next to a water glass one morning. I was groggy that morning, but have no idea just how much I took of any of my other prescriptions. After three nights, when I tried to stop using it, I could not sleep at all.  It took nearly three weeks for my sleep to return to the pre-Ambien status -- which isn't good or I wouldn't have taken it to begin with.
Ambien is highly addictive. I used half of a 5mg tablet 3 days in a row and can no longer sleep without it.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
column9: I've tried other sleep aids and none of them worked.  Ambien works quickly and lets me sleep ALL night (on most others, I wake up after a few hours).  Unlike over the counter sleep aids, there's no "hangover."  I'll take 5 mg to 10 mg when I need it.The highly publicized sleep-eating phenomenon is an actual issue but easily avoided.  Do not consume any alcohol the night you're going to take it.  Get in bed AS SOON as you take it and don't get up.  If anything weird happens, consider upping your dose--it seems to result from people being half-asleep (basically, awake but stoned), and taking a sufficient amount seems to help.And be sure to allow 8 hours after you take it until you have to wake up.In all, very very highly recommended, just use it with caution; it's a controlled substance for a reason.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient)
25-34 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years
column9: An effective & fast-acting sleep aid. I had no side effects. Some ppl complain of amnesia and even hallucinations but I  had no such problems & don't know anyone who did. It's the only sleep aid I've tried that has continued to work for my chronic insomnia. All the others I tried - benzodiazepines, trazodone, antihistamines like Benadryl and Atarax, Lunesta - either didn't work at all, or stopped working after a few nights, but I'm still taking the same dose of Ambien after several years, no tolerance. My only complaint is that it only lasts a few hours. I was not impressed with Ambien CR. Oh, also, the 10mg dose that is supposed to work for everybody, it doesn't work for me & I know several others who say the same. So if 10 doesn't work don't give up on it, 15 or 20 might still work. It's most reliable if you take it on an empty stomach, so if you tried it after eating or with food, that might be another reason why it wouldn't work.
